description: From Middle French ombre (“umber”), from terre d'ombre (“dark ochre”), from Old French umbre (“shade, shadow”), from Latin umbra. Doublet of umbra.

entries.meaning: Of a reddish brown colour, like that of the pigment.
examples: Their harps are of the umber shade / That hides the blush of waking day.

entries.meaning: A brown clay, somewhat darker than ochre, which contains iron and manganese oxides.
A dusky brown African wading bird (Scopus umbretta) allied to the shoebill and herons; a hamerkop.

verbs.description: umber (third-person singular simple present umbers, present participle umbering, simple past and past participle umbered)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To give a reddish-brown colour to.
examples: Armies o'er armies heap'd, the locusts came,Like clouds in autumn umbering all the sky  […]
